guide.introduction:
Motion-controlled time-lapse photography has become increasingly popular among professional as well as hobby photographers in the last couple of years.

With the availability of low cost open source motion control gear and digital SLR cameras, the realm of high end time-lapse shooting is now open to anyone willing to invest a little money and lots of time.

If you want to read about how to time-lapse, check out the forum at Timescapes.org.

An excellent source of information about timelapse is Gunter Wegners timelapse ebook, which you can purchase in his shop at LRTimelapse.com

LRTimelapse, by the way is an great tool for timelapse post processing. There is a free evaluation version available. If you are seriously into timelapse (which you probably are if you have read this far), give it a shot, you won't regret it.

There are quite a few open source sliders (like the Dynamic Perception Stage Zero or Stage One dolly or the eMotimo TB-3 pan and tilt head) on the market now, but there haven't been any reasonably priced or easy-to-use lens motors.

I made this motor for use with my eMotimo TB-3, which is capable of driving a third stepper motor (in addition to the pan and tilt axes). But you can also drive the motor with any stepper driver, for example the Easydriver or the Dynamic Percpetion NanoMoco boards.

When used with stop-motion software like Dragonframe, the TB-3 and the OLC Motor can also be used for stop-motion animation.

I tried to make the motor as easy to build as possible. If you have access to a 3D printer you need very few parts to assemble the motor.

Basically, anyone who can hold a screwdriver should have no problems assembling the motor.

I have taken great care in writing these instructions. If you find issues or errors, please tell me: kid@kids-of-all-ages.de

If you want to participate in the further development of the motor and the OLC, feel free to check out our website frequently.

Relevant parts
  • Open Lens Control Motor Shell left side
  • Open Lens Control Motor Shell right side
  • 1x 0.8 module gear 56 teeth
  • Worm gear
  • Stainless steel axis
  • Flange Bearing 8 mm / 5 mm / 2 mm
  • Clamp On Rings
  • Roller
  • Stepper Motor Nema 8
Tools
  • 1x Hex Wrench 1,5 mm
  • 1x Wrench 5,5 mm
  • Hack saw
  • Hex Wrench 2,5 mm
  • MakerBot Thing-O-Matic 3D Printer Kit (optional)
  • mill bastard file

parts.text: Open Lens Control Motor Shell left side
Open Lens Control Motor Shell right side

lines.text: Cut a 45 mm piece from the stainless steel rod using your hacksaw. With the file, clean the edges.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 45 mm piece from the stainless steel rod using your hacksaw. With the file, clean the edges.

lines.text: Drill a 10 mm hole in the gear and insert the roller. Then slide the axle into the roller.
lines.text_raw: Drill a 10 mm hole in the gear and insert the roller. Then slide the axle into the roller.

lines.text: The 56-tooth gear has a hub on one side. Slide one locking ring on to the axle from the other side.
lines.text_raw: The 56-tooth gear has a hub on one side. Slide one locking ring on to the axle from the other side.

lines.text: Center the gear on the axle (just sort of..).
lines.text_raw: Center the gear on the axle (just sort of..).

lines.text: Lock the locking ring in place.
lines.text_raw: Lock the locking ring in place.

lines.text: Insert the bearings into the holes from the outside of the shell.
lines.text_raw: Insert the bearings into the holes from the outside of the shell.

lines.text: Slide the axle into the bearing from the inside. It does not matter which way.
lines.text_raw: Slide the axle into the bearing from the inside. It does not matter which way.

lines.text: Install the worm gear on the motor by sliding it on. You might need pliers to accomlish this; the gear is pretty tight. The hub needs to go on the motor side of the shaft.
lines.text_raw: Install the worm gear on the motor by sliding it on. You might need pliers to accomlish this; the gear is pretty tight. The hub needs to go on the motor side of the shaft.

lines.text: Then put the motor into the shell as shown in the picture. Make sure the teeth of the gear engage into the worm's teeth.
lines.text_raw: Then put the motor into the shell as shown in the picture. Make sure the teeth of the gear engage into the worm's teeth.

lines.text: According to the data sheets, the pitch of the worm is 0.75 and the pitch of the gear is 0.8. However, both seem to fit together just fine. In the long run, I want to make 3D models of both available, the worm and the gear, which will solve this issue.
lines.text_raw: According to the data sheets, the pitch of the worm is 0.75 and the pitch of the gear is 0.8. However, both seem to fit together just fine. In the long run, I want to make 3D models of both available, the worm and the gear, which will solve this issue.

lines.text: In my prototype, the motor had a little bit of play in the shell, so I used thin washers to lock it in place.
lines.text_raw: In my prototype, the motor had a little bit of play in the shell, so I used thin washers to lock it in place.

lines.text: Now put both parts of the shell together and slide the bearing over the axle until it is in place. This might feel a little tight, so you want to wiggle the shell and axle a little until everything is in place.
lines.text_raw: Now put both parts of the shell together and slide the bearing over the axle until it is in place. This might feel a little tight, so you want to wiggle the shell and axle a little until everything is in place.

lines.text: You are almost there.
lines.text_raw: You are almost there.

lines.text: Now slide the locking rings onto the axle on either side and lock them into position.
lines.text_raw: Now slide the locking rings onto the axle on either side and lock them into position.

lines.text: Screw in the M3 Bolts.
lines.text_raw: Screw in the M3 Bolts.

lines.text: Tighten the bolts using a wrench. I used self-locking nuts, but that is not very important. It just makes the motor look nicer, I think.
lines.text_raw: Tighten the bolts using a wrench. I used self-locking nuts, but that is not very important. It just makes the motor look nicer, I think.

lines.text: Use the short M3 bolts to create a simple locking mechanism. With this bolt, you can lock the motor easily on a 15 mm rod.
lines.text_raw: Use the short M3 bolts to create a simple locking mechanism. With this bolt, you can lock the motor easily on a 15 mm rod.

lines.text: You are done! Now you can mount the motor on a 15 mm camera rig and connect it to your stepper driver.
lines.text_raw: You are done! Now you can mount the motor on a 15 mm camera rig and connect it to your stepper driver.

lines.text: You can find out more about the motor pin-out, etc., here.
lines.text_raw: You can find out more about the motor pin-out, etc., [http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1204|here].

lines.text: When you operate the motor with an eMotimo TB-3, it might get really hot. This usually does not hurt it and is quite normal. You can adjust the motor power in the eMotimo (if you know how to do that), but be aware that the motor will be less powerful if you do so.

guide.summary: This lens motor was designed to be as simple and easy to make as possible, yet it is capable of driving professional film or DSLR lenses.
